text:
It seems that servlet and servlet-mapping tags cannot be intermixed in
web.xml.

Example snippet from a  web.xml:

    <servlet>
        <servlet-name>snoop</servlet-name>
        <servlet-class>SnoopServlet</servlet-class>
    </servlet>
    <servlet-mapping>
        <servlet-name>snoop</servlet-name>
        <url-pattern>/snoop</url-pattern>
    </servlet-mapping>
    <servlet>
      <servlet-name>servletToJsp</servlet-name>
      <servlet-class>servletToJsp</servlet-class>
    </servlet>

This fails with:

> PARSE error at line 121 column -1
> org.xml.sax.SAXParseException: org.apache.crimson.parser/V-036 web-app servlet

It works when the <servlet-mapping> is moved after the last
<servlet>-Tag.


-Stefan
creator: winter@dfki.de

text:
The elements in your web.xml file must conform to the DTD as documented in the
Servlet Specification, which you can download at:

http://java.sun.com/products/servlet/download.html

In particular, the DTD has very strict rules about the ordering of elements, and
(among other things) all <servlet> elements *must* come before all
<servlet-mapping> elements.  See Chapter 13 of the spec for details.

Tomcat 3.x did not enforce this requirement.  Tomcat 4 does, however, because it
uses a validating XML parser.

text:
Then the spec is broken :)

Seriously, from an engeneering standpoint, I doubt this is a wise decision, 
since a lot of web applications that worked fine on the "reference platform" 
(Tomcat 3) will suddenly break when going to Tomcat 4. Also, Tomcat 4 will be 
the _only_ app server (that I know of) that cannot cope with this.

And I thought all that hassle with XML was to avoid problems with parsing config 
files...

While saying "it's the spec" is formally correct, it will not make you many 
friends in the "real world" out there. Any chance of changing the spec?

Just my $.02
-Stefan
